verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: This begins a new section of laws addressing the sanctity required from priests. As in many places, divine instruction comes directly to Moses as intercessor (cf. Lev. 21:1).

verses.text: Speak to Aaron and his sons, so that they keep themselves separate from the holy offerings of the Israelites, which they dedicate to me, and do not profane my holy name. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: This stresses the necessity for the priests’ sanctity. The separation from the offerings underlines the importance of reverence and purity in handling sacred things—a theme found throughout Scripture and seen fulfilled in Christ's high priesthood (Heb. 7:26-28).

verses.text: Say to them: If any one of all your descendants throughout your generations approaches the holy things which the Israelites dedicate to the Lord while he is unclean, that person shall be cut off from my presence. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: Being "cut off" often refers to exclusion from the community or worse. Note the gravity of approaching the sacred unworthily—an idea present in New Testament warnings about receiving the Lord’s Supper unworthily (1 Cor. 11:27-30).

verses.text: None of Aaron’s offspring who has leprosy, or a discharge, may eat of the holy things until he is clean. Whoever touches anything made unclean by a corpse, or has an emission of semen,
verses.comment: This verse carefully lists conditions of uncleanness. Ritual purity points to the necessity of spiritual purity, later fulfilled in Christ and the sacraments that cleanse spiritually (John 13:8-10).

verses.text: or whoever touches any crawling thing by which he may be made unclean, or a person who makes him unclean, whatever his uncleanness may be—
verses.comment: Touches on the transmission of legal uncleanness by contact. The distinction between clean and unclean foreshadows the New Testament call to holiness in all aspects of life (1 Peter 1:15-16).

verses.text: the person who touches any of these shall be unclean until the evening, and shall not eat of the holy things, unless he bathes his body in water.
verses.comment: Physical washing as preparation for sacred participation. Water here prefigures the cleansing that comes through Christian baptism, which purifies believers not only ritually but spiritually (Acts 22:16).

verses.text: When the sun goes down, he becomes clean, and afterward he may eat of the holy things, because that is his food.
verses.comment: The timing of purification—marked by sunset—reflects Old Testament concern for ritual cycles. Priests rely on these holy things for their provision, anticipating the Church’s later understanding of sacred ministry and holy orders sustaining its ministers.

verses.text: He shall not eat what dies of itself or is torn by beasts, making himself unclean by it. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: This precept is a reminder that not everything edible is permissible; it draws boundaries around holiness and foreshadows the need for discernment in receiving what is sacred—especially notable in the practice of the Lord’s Table (1 Cor. 11:29).

verses.text: They shall therefore keep my charge, lest they bear sin for it and die thereby if they profane it. I am the Lord who sanctifies them.
verses.comment: Sanctification is the Lord’s work, but requires human cooperation with His commands. This balance between divine initiative and human response is echoed in New Testament exhortations to pursue holiness (Heb. 12:14).

verses.text: No outsider shall eat of a holy thing. A sojourner with the priest, or a hired servant, shall not eat of a holy thing.
verses.comment: Only those specifically set apart can partake—pointing to the Church’s later practice of restricting participation in the sacraments to those properly initiated and prepared.

verses.text: But if a priest buys a slave as his property, that person may eat of it, and anyone born in his house may eat of his food.
verses.comment: Being part of the priest’s household, even through servitude, grants access—illustrating the importance of spiritual household membership, echoed in being adopted into God’s family through faith and the sacraments.

verses.text: If a priest’s daughter marries an outsider, she shall not eat of the holy contribution.
verses.comment: Family ties to the priesthood are considered carefully. Leaving the house of the priest (e.g., by marriage) dissolves prior access to sacred food, illustrating how true participation in sacred things is tied to right relationship and incorporation into the community of faith.

verses.text: But if the priest’s daughter is widowed or divorced, has no child, and returns to her father’s house as in her youth, she may eat of her father’s food. But no outsider may eat of it.
verses.comment: Returning to the father’s household after marital loss restores access to the holy food. This is a pattern seen later in the parable of the prodigal son (Luke 15:17-20), suggesting God’s mercy and restoration of those who return.

verses.text: If anyone eats of a holy thing unintentionally, he shall add one-fifth to it and give the holy thing to the priest.
verses.comment: Unintentional offenses require restitution plus a penalty, underlining not only justice but also the concern for reparation and restoration, found also in Christian practice (see Mt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: They shall not profane the holy offerings of the Israelites, which they contribute to the Lord,
verses.comment: Guarding the sanctity of offerings is essential. The idea is later spiritualized, showing that the Church is to be a pure and set-apart people (see 1 Peter 2:9).

verses.text: and so cause them to bear iniquity and guilt by eating their holy offerings; for I am the Lord who makes them holy.
verses.comment: Priests bear responsibility both for their own sanctity and the sanctity of the people—foreshadowing the spiritual leadership and shepherding roles found in the New Testament church (see John 21:15-17).

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Another formulaic introduction to a new instruction. The repetition emphasizes both the seriousness and the continuity of God’s commands to His covenant people.

verses.text: Speak to Aaron and his sons and all the people of Israel, and say to them: When anyone of the house of Israel or of the foreigners in Israel presents their offering, whether for any of their vows or as a freewill offering that they present to the Lord as a burnt offering,
verses.comment: Note even the foreigner is included, suggesting God’s inclusivity and prefiguring the later opening of salvation to all nations (Acts 10:34-35).

verses.text: to be accepted, the offering must be a male without blemish, from the cattle, sheep, or goats.
verses.comment: The demand for unblemished sacrifices points forward to Christ, the sinless Lamb offered for humanity’s redemption (1 Peter 1:18-19).

verses.text: You shall not offer anything that has a blemish, for it will not be acceptable for you.
verses.comment: The perfect, unblemished offering typifies Christ’s sinlessness—making Him the only fitting mediator (cf. Heb. 9:14).

verses.text: And when anyone offers a sacrifice of peace offerings to the Lord to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering, whether from the herd or the flock, it must be perfect to be accepted; there shall be no blemish in it.
verses.comment: The call for perfection in sacrifice anticipates Christ’s perfect self-offering for peace with God (Col. 1:20).

verses.text: Animals blind or disabled, or with mutilated or missing parts, or with sores, scabs, or skin disease, you shall not offer to the Lord or make a food offering by fire on the altar to the Lord.
verses.comment: More specific requirements reinforce the standard of total offering, an image later spiritualized to call for disciples to give their whole selves to God (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: A bull or a lamb that has a deformed or stunted limb you may offer as a freewill offering, but it will not be accepted for a vow.
verses.comment: God’s standards for regular offerings and vows differ; vows require the highest standard, illustrating the seriousness of pledges made to God.

verses.text: Any animal with its testicles bruised, crushed, torn, or cut, you shall not offer to the Lord. You shall not do this in your land,
verses.comment: Even seemingly minor defects are cause for exclusion from sacrifice, stressing reverence and care in all things dedicated to God.

verses.text: and you shall not accept such animals from a foreigner to offer as the bread of your God, because their deformity or defect makes them unacceptable for you.
verses.comment: Foreign offerings are held to the same high standard, confirming the universality yet specificity of God’s call to holiness.

verses.text: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Transitional statement introducing regulations for the age of sacrificial animals.

verses.text: When an ox or a sheep or a goat is born, it shall remain with its mother seven days; from the eighth day on it shall be accepted as a food offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: Animals must reach a minimal age, paralleling later Christian practices about preparation and maturity before receiving the sacraments.

verses.text: But you shall not slaughter an ox or a sheep and its young on the same day.
verses.comment: Instruction against killing animal and its young on the same day reflects God’s concern for mercy, a virtue expected of His people (Hosea 6:6).

verses.text: When you sacrifice a thanksgiving offering to the Lord, you shall sacrifice it so that you may be accepted.
verses.comment: Thank offerings must be made acceptably—worship offered on God’s terms, not merely human initiative, is what pleases Him (Heb. 12:28).

verses.text: It must be eaten on the same day; you shall leave none of it until morning. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: The immediacy is reminiscent of the Passover lamb, which itself points forward to the true sacrificial feast of Christ, fulfilled in the new covenant meal taken with reverence and promptness (Matt. 26:26-28).

verses.text: So you shall keep my commandments and do them. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s authority as source and guarantor of holiness is reinforced. Obedience to divine command is a perpetual theme in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: You shall not profane my holy name, but I will be sanctified among the people of Israel. I am the Lord who makes you holy,
verses.comment: God’s name is to be revered. The call to sanctify the Lord’s name is later echoed in the Lord’s Prayer, stressing the continuity of Old and New Covenant worship.

verses.text: who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God: I am the Lord.
verses.comment: The Lord’s redemptive work for Israel points forward to the greater redemption in Christ—a people delivered and formed to be His own, called to worship Him in spirit and truth.
